Child related payments paid to service pensioners are matched to the rate of Social Security additional family payment. This measure will ensure that the rates continue to be matched by providing that a similar increase will apply to service pensioners with dependent children.

The final initiative relates to the reinstatement of the payment of advance pharmaceutical allowance. Advance pharmaceutical allowance was paid to chronically ill pensioners with a high volume of prescription drug use. The advance payment was made from 1991 to 1993. Payments ceased from 1 January 1994 as a result of the operation of a sunset clause. A proposal was included in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 to extend the sunset clause for a further year. This bill failed to become operative due to the Senate's refusal to pass the bill in its original form. The disagreement of the Senate was not related to advance pharmaceutical allowance.

The initiative in the current bill is to re-introduce advance pharmaceutical allowance payments from 1 January 1995 without the inclusion of a sunset clause. This will ensure that the availability of the advance will be an ongoing benefit to veterans and their dependants. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the opposition against does not oppose any of the measures outlined in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), and I will not repeat my remarks about the time we had to consider them, we will naturally reserve our position in the Senate later on. They are very specific measures for which I do not anticipate any opposition. Nevertheless, having said that and having been very moderate in my earlier remarks, I have to point out to the chamber some of the politics associated with these particular measures because they do the government no credit. The bill could almost be called the bill of broken promises.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I want to talk about the government's hypocrisy in bringing again to the parliament its arrangements to increase the retirement age at which women become eligible for, in this case, the service pension. I note that the government has maintained the differential between service pensioners and normal public pensioners of five years. I endorse that, naturally, but we have to look at the history of this matter. It stems from the 1993 Budget when the House was informed that women generally live longer than men and that their participation in the labour force and level of wages could be expected to further increase. We were told that raising the pension age would reduce the likelihood of women being forced to retire at 60 as there would no longer be an expectation that women could claim the age pension at this age.

That is, of course, something that we did not oppose because, in the context of everything we did at the last election, we put it on the table. We let the voters know what our position was. They rejected us on some of those matters and this, no doubt, was one of them, particularly when we look at what the government had to say about our position prior to the last election.This is the sort of thing that was said, in this case by the then Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett:

SPEECH.PARA: The lower pension age for women is due recognition of the fact that many older women devoted most of their lives to their families and sacrificed employment, savings and superannuation in the process. When women of pension age have had similar opportunities to their male counterparts, that will be the time to equalise pension ages, not before.

That was the government's position before the election. I have just read what it said in the first budget after the election. But it is worse than that because Dr Blewett went on with the dreadful situation that occurred during the election, when the truth was just slaughtered day after day. What did he say? Dr Blewett described the coalition's policies as `premature, ill-considered, extremely harsh and unfair'. I know he has gone, but how can we be dealing with this matter? It was brought in by this government, not ours? We stated our position; we are clear. That is why we are not opposing the bill; we are not going to be hypocrites. But it is time that it was drawn to the attention of those opposite how they played that election and how they played the people—not us. It is nice to say, `We beat you again.' It is not a cricket match; it is not a footy match. It is a case of the people who got dealt to and the people were very put out about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the opinion polls say?

—Do not make jokes about it because we are talking about that. Do the opinion polls say that people think the government was honest in the last election? No, they do not. When Jim Short, the then opposition finance spokesman, claimed that the government had a similar policy, Dr Blewett denied this emphatically. He went on to claim that this policy—our policy, the policy that the government is implementing here today—would see women in their 40s and 50s having to alter their retirement plans drastically. For many, it would mean a substantial loss of income and late age entry into the unemployment queues. If that was the case then, those opposite should tell us what is different today.

PARA.TAB: The government has had some embarrassment about this and its solution was to form a caucus committee. I would not be at all surprised if the member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) is a member of it. It was set up to investigate the possibility of reversing this decision. That was the first one, when the government brought in its social security measures. If that caucus committee wants a message from government, from the executive, it has it today. But what hypocrisy to be running a caucus committee that is supposed to be considering the reversal of the original piece of legislation when, here today, we have a piece of legislation that extends that age determination to people in receipt of veterans pensions.

I hope that the member for Bass does not get up and say how she is still fighting for these people, because, obviously, she is not. If she had a personal commitment, she has been rolled. The simple fact is that we do not want any of that hypocrisy, and this is an exercise in hypocrisy. The honourable member can say, `Go look at the polls,' but it does not change the simple fact that I stand here as a representative of the people you are affecting too. Those opposite sold them a bill of goods. We did not, and we are not going to reverse our position and be hypocrites in taking the political opportunities that would arise from going out and kicking hell out of members of the government on this issue, as they kicked hell out of us on that occasion. The difference is that we can both sleep at night but for different reasons. The government has no sense, no feeling. It is an outrageous situation that a government could go to the people, as it did, on this and other issues and, in fact, reverse its position immediately.

The third item in this particular area increases the maximum rate of additional family payment by $1 a week. Why did the government do that? Because it broke another promise: the no tax promise; the l-a-w promise. The government dumped a substantial amount of cost of living increases on the community. It realised it put certain lower income groups in such poverty that it had to do something about it. The government increased the additional family payment by $1 to try to compensate at least some of the community. The government then

SPEECH.PARA: dumped 5c a litre petrol increase on this group of people as most of them were still driving cars using leaded fuel.

PARA.TAB: We do not oppose what the government is doing. Both of those issues that have been addressed today are compensation for a broken promise. This was a promise that many Australians did not receive and many Australians just had to pay the money. One of these compensations may appear generous—it is a gift. If everybody was compensated, the budget would have to be balanced and the money so desperately needed before the election would not be there. That is another part of this outrageous situation.

Historically, oppositions have come to power and broken promises simply because they could claim—and do so honestly from either side of politics—that they did not know the full state of affairs; they had not seen the government's accounts. When you are in government, all the figures are there. It is totally dishonest to say, `We have had to impose all these taxes. We have had to break all these promises because we did not know the gun was loaded.' Of course the government knew the gun was loaded.

More importantly, on the issue of extending the age for the eligibility of the aged pension for women, the government blatantly attacked our proposition. It clearly indicated to the people of Australia that the government did not intend doing what is being done here today. It brings the government no credit. I do not give a dash how the government's circumstances stand in the opinion polls. It does not change the fact that the people of Australia were misled on this particular issue by the government's side of politics. It is no good.

In the House the other day, I pointed out how frequently we have supported the government on the basis of our philosophy and how we allowed it to achieve economic reform. I pointed out how easy it might have been for us to have prevented the sale of portions of the Commonwealth Bank. It was an icon. The government knows very well how it would have dealt with the matter—it would have found its instructions in its little black book—if we had been in government and had announced an intention to sell part of the Commonwealth Bank. The government can give us a lesson in politics, if it likes. For goodness sake! It is all a matter of hypocrisy. We are supporting the government today—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the veterans.

—A few of them might have banked at the Commonwealth Bank—I'll take a bet on it—if you want me to give you a linkage. On all of these issues, we could have stopped the government from doing things but, if we had stopped the government, it would not have been good for Australia. So we did not. It is not a bad lesson to learn from time to time. There can often be a sound reason to change the pension age, but the government played politics with it until it was re-elected.

PARA.TAB: Today, we find ourselves passing legislation which the government said would not happen under its administration. As I said, it becomes high farce when a caucus committee is formed to reverse it and when, having formed the committee, and while it is still in existence, the government runs around and passes additional legislation to achieve the same result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Turn the other cheek.

—No, we do not turn cheeks. It will go on the record and I will have the opportunity from time to time to remind a lot of female veterans about what happened and how they were misled at the time. That is a matter of history and, as I said, it is not an issue that we could ignore.

PARA.TAB: To go back to other aspects of the legislation, we understand and we welcome the reintroduction of payments of advanced pharmaceutical allowance for the chronically ill. We understand what happened there. It is possibly a good question as to why it has taken this long to get it reinstated, considering it all fell over on 1 January 1994, but it is being done, on this occasion without a sunset clause. So we will not confront this problem again and we do not object to that—we welcome it. They are the only issues covered in this particular legislation.

The minister has clearly enunciated how we will move from the present age eligibility to the new arrangement by increasing the age threshold by six months every two years, and that also is quite acceptable. We do not have any opposition to this legislation, but we put on the record that it does represent a substantial misleading of the Australian people at the last election. It brings no credit to any government that on such a fundamental issue where such clear, precise statements were made about the position, it was the next best thing to another `l-a-w, law' statement, and it was a misleading of the people. That brings no credit to anyone. We have no other remarks to make on this legislation and we do not oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It always interesting to follow the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I was listening to him earlier today as well. I thought we had a bipartisan approach in this Main Committee where non-controversial legislation has the support of both sides of the parliament. The member for O'Connor can always make something that is non-controversial into something quite controversial. I am sure the other speakers on this side will respond in a lot more detail than I have the time to do this morning.

PARA.TAB: The member for O'Connor did make particular reference to the qualifying age changes that are proposed, which brings this legislation in line with the social security legislation. The minister also mentioned that in his second reading speech.

I wish to raise the matter of the advanced pharmaceutical allowance. That is a very important issue amongst the veteran community. I consider the bill's proposal to address the problem we have with the pharmaceutical allowance as a major amendment. This legislation actually allows for the re-introduction of the advanced pharmaceutical allowance which was previously cut off due to a sunset clause in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2). I am really pleased that this is being addressed here today.

This bill provides for the reintroduction of that allowance starting from 1 January next year. No doubt that will be a very welcome new year present to our veteran community. All of us, as members, are in constant contact with our veteran community. Given the advanced age of many of our veterans, this initiative is a very worthy one and deserves the support of all members of this place. The advance pharmaceutical allowance was originally made available to chronically ill pensioners with a high volume of prescription drug use. When the date in the sunset clause was reached before amending legislation was dealt with by the parliament the allowance was cancelled, and that has been a concern. This bill will now not only reintroduce the advanced allowance for this category of pensioners, but also ensure that the scheme is not subject to any other sunset clauses. That is a real plus and a good initiative for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) to take.
I am particularly happy to support this aspect of the bill. I have several veterans in my electorate—as we all have—who have raised this issue with me, some of whom of course I am lucky to—

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! We have no member from the opposition here and the standing orders say that we have to have a member from the opposition. We have stopped the clock so you are not being counted out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is certainly a learning experience. It is quite interesting. The honourable member for O'Connor just walked out on me! That was a major impact. I was supporting the legislation, though not in the same terms as he was. I am pleased to support it. I was just making reference to return of the advance pharmaceutical allowance through this bill, which I really welcome.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly happy to support this aspect of the bill, as I have many veterans in my community who have raised this issue with me. Many of those veterans, whom I am pleased to call my friends, support the initiatives that this government has introduced on behalf of the veterans community.

The age of many of our veterans places them in the category of those who will be more susceptible to chronic illness. They deserve all the help that we can give them and this government has responded to their need. Also, their chronic illness may have some connection to their wartime experience. I, like other members of the government, have a moral obligation to help those veterans with their pharmaceutical costs. I am very pleased that this is happening here.

Indeed, this bill is another innovative plank in the government's reforms on behalf of veterans. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) is to be congratulated for his ongoing commitment to our veterans, as are previous veterans' affairs ministers. I make particular reference to Senator Faulkner and the member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), who, in this government, certainly had that long-term commitment.

In this context, I mention someone in my electorate whom the minister at the table has actually met before, a gentlemen called Bill Langford, a veteran from the Second World War. Bill was in the Middle East during the war and he is a tremendous fellow. I mentioned earlier, when speaking on another bill, that the minister visited the Goodwin RSL Club; it was the first RSL club that he visited after becoming the minister. Bill came in from Laidley, which is in the western part of my electorate, to share the day with us and managed to get his photo in the paper with the minister. Bill was certainly very pleased to participate in that event.

Bill is one of those to benefit from the government's changes in regard to hospital treatment, because it means that now he can get a bus or train from Laidley into Ipswich, which is a 45-minute trip, and be treated at a private hospital in Ipswich, instead of having to go to Greenslopes in Brisbane. This is a great help to his wife, Margaret, who does not drive a car; she would have to travel for three hours to see him at Greenslopes Hospital. But now she can come into Ipswich, which is just down the road from my electoral office. When she visits Ipswich, she drops into my office, at my invitation, to have a cup of tea at my office. They are lovely people. Their situation is an example of how we have helped our veterans in that area.

I do not want wish to speak for too long, because we want to get this bill through, and others as well. I just want to indicate my support for that particular aspect of this bill, and for the advance pharmaceutical allowance. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise here today to speak on the Veterans Affairs' Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1994. This bill will bring the veterans pensions into line with the aged pension by increasing the qualifying age at which women can apply for the aged service pension from 55 to 65 years, over a 10-year period. The bill will also reintroduce the advance pharmaceutical allowance from January next year. This is a measure that is welcome. Thirdly, the bill will increase the maximum rate of the dependent child add-on by $52 a year for service pensioners with children under 16 years of age.

PARA.TAB: This change to the pension entitlements for women is a reflection of the change that was included in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) of 1994. The reason for this is simple. The original distinction between the pension ages for men and women was based on the fact that, in the past, there was a much lower labour force participation rate for women.

I stand here today, as a particularly happy and proud woman, to say that this is one of the areas where women are definitely making inroads. The statistics bear those inroads out. It is because of that increased participation rate in the work force for women that the pension age for women will slowly be increased from the current level of 55 years to 60 years. The first increment will take place on 1 July 1995. The phasing in will be entirely equitable, and will take place over an extended period of time. This method of implementation recognises the remaining labour force disadvantages incurred over the years by the older women affected by these measures.I must stress, however, that the great bulk of female veterans will not be affected by these measures, because they are already older than 63 and in receipt of the service pension. The small number of women who would have qualified at 55, and who now, under this new system, will not, will have access to labour force programs and supporting measures like the jobsearch allowance. We are not leaving them behind at any time. Women veterans who have a permanent incapacity which prevents them from working will continue to have access to the invalid service pension at any age.

As I have already stated, these changes will be implemented over a long period of time. Every two years the pension age for women will increase by six months. Increments will occur progressively on this basis until 1 January 2014. At this time, the pensionable age will be 60 years. A woman will attain pensionable age only once. Once a woman attains the age where she can claim a pension, she is eligible for that pension from then on. This is the case even if she does not claim the pension at that particular time. The reason for this is that, under the strictest possible application of the formula for the pension, it is possible for a woman to obtain pensionable age and then lose it. This bill makes sure that once pensionable age is attained it is maintained.

The second major provision of this bill is the reintroduction of provisions for the payment of the advance pharmaceutical allowance, which will take effect from 1 January 1995. From 1 November 1990, provision was made for chronically ill pensioners who constantly used a high volume of drugs to have access to the advance pharmaceutical allowance. This was initially introduced for a period of one year, and was later extended for a further two years. These provisions were later removed. The bill we have before us today will reintroduce access to that facility. With the passage of this bill, from 1 January 1995 the advance pharmaceutical allowance will again be paid. As well as the fact that this facility will be reintroduced, it will also no longer be subject to sunset provisions. The ability to gain payment of the advance pharmaceutical allowance is back, and it is here to stay.

The third major provision of this bill is to increase the level of dependent child add-on for service pensioners with children who have not yet turned 16. This rate will be increased by $52 per year. This measure essentially stems from the 1993 budget process. The decision was taken at that time that, from 1 January 1995, the highest rate of additional family payment should be raised by $1 per week for every child under 16. The basis for this measure was to help low income earners and the unemployed to offset the 1993 budget increase in the wholesale tax. This bill proposes that $52 per year be added to the under-13 and the over-13 but under-16 add-on rates for dependent children, and will take effect from 1 January 1995.

In reality, this provision really brings service pensioners into line with additional family payments under the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act has already been amended to increase that additional family payment. This bill will pass those changes on to service pensioners with dependent children that come under the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlement Act.

This is essentially a small bill, and it represents a very small part of this government's plans and program for Australian veterans. The Australian government has an overall veterans program which is the envy of many governments and many individual veterans throughout the world. Make no mistake: this government looks after its veteran community very, very well. There are some governments which have been involved in some of the same conflicts as Australia but do not even have a federal department of veterans' affairs.

We as a nation are also very lucky to have a minister for veterans' affairs who is as dedicated and as enthusiastic as the one we have in the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca). His `Australia Remembers' program is excellent, and has generated a huge amount of interest nationally, and especially within my own electorate of Bass. In fact, the minister was very recently in my electorate to promote his veterans program. We conducted an afternoon tea at the Launceston RSL, and it was attended by some 110 members of the local veterans community. It was a fantastic function.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes; and your husband got you the name of the people to write to, which was pretty improper!

—Wrong! The minister and I spent a couple of hours talking to the veterans on a one-to-one basis. There is no mistaking the fact that our current minister for veterans' affairs is a grassroots minister and that the programs which he promotes are grassroots programs which the veterans actually want. The minister received a wonderful reception at the Launceston RSL, and many in the veteran community whom I know personally and have constant dealings with are already asking me when he is coming back to northern Tasmania. It cannot be too soon, as far as I am concerned.

PARA.TAB: We have a very strong veteran community in northern Tasmania. This is a community which is close-knit and supportive of its own. I cannot sing too highly the praises of those veterans who devote almost all of their time to the service of their mates. One such individual I would like to mention—and the minister himself has met with this gentleman, and I am sure will reiterate what I am about to say—is a man called Bob Fitz. He is not only a man to respect and admire for his tireless service to the veteran community of northern Tasmania, but also a man whom I am pleased and proud to be able to call a very close friend.

Bob Fitz is constantly helping veterans, in the formal sense. He helps them with applications, and he appears as an advocate for them before panels of review; but that is not where it stops: Bob is also a counsellor to his mates. As in all veteran communities in Australia, northern Tasmania has veterans who are on the edge. For some veterans, the pressure is still too great: the memories are still too real, and the horror is still too close. The people in this place should never forget that fact, and they should never forget the sacrifice that these people have made and are still making.

Bob Fitz helps these veterans. He talks with them at all hours of the day or night. He visits them. He has a drink with them, and he supports them. These people turn to Bob Fitz when they will not turn to anyone else, and they do so because he is one of them. He has been through what they have been through. He has experienced what they have experienced, and he has dealt with it. There are very few professional counsellors with that sort of experience, and I will bet there are very few who are as effective. The work of people such as Bob Fitz is one way in which the veteran community of northern Tasmania is served.

A former Deputy Prime Minister, Lance Barnard, also serves the veteran community. I am in the particularly lucky position of having Lance Barnard still serving the community—especially the veteran community—through my office. For those members and others here today who do not know Lance Barnard, he held the seat of Bass for 21 years and became Deputy Prime Minister under Gough Whitlam in 1972. He was Minister for Defence from 1972 to 1975, when he retired. It is because of that position, and the fact that he is a World War II veteran and has held the position of Director of the Office of Australian War Graves, that Lance Barnard has such a great interest in the veteran community of northern Tasmania.

Gough Whitlam once described Lance as one of the bravest men he knew. This was because Lance had fought at El Alamein, and had, as Minister for Defence, actually flown the F111—a brave thing to do, I am thinking! Lance Barnard works out of my office. He gives his time freely and he works as tirelessly now as when he was still the member for Bass. I might add that Lance Barnard turned 75 on May 1 this year. He has never retired.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present member is equally as good though.

—Thank you. Lance Barnard takes the vast percentage of the veterans' affairs caseload that comes through my office, and he gets results. I have to say that I find it quite amusing that officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs tend to snap to their task pretty quickly when they find that a query is from Lance Barnard. He is tireless in his work in this area. He is constantly helping veterans make applications and he is constantly appearing before various review boards on their behalf.

PARA.TAB: Most of the veterans community of northern Tasmania would know Lance Barnard and most of them would have been helped by him directly or indirectly at some time. I pay tribute to Lance Barnard. He is indeed a rare individual. I think honourable members would find that most people, after a lengthy career in public life, would like to drop out totally or relax at home. Lance Barnard is not like that. The work Lance does now in his retirement shows that he was not like many politicians. He entered politics for the right reason. He genuinely wanted to serve the community. Even in his retirement, Lance Barnard is serving the community. I cannot pay him any greater tribute than to say, `Thank you, Lance, for that commitment.' He is someone that I genuinely aspire to be like as a politician and as a person.

I have spoken today of two individuals who have worked tirelessly for the veterans community of northern Tasmania. These people are an example of how importantly the veterans community is regarded by the general community. The bill which we debate today is just a small part of that commitment of this government. We should never forget the role that veterans have played for this nation and the international esteem which they brought to this country. We should never forget the veterans. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a privilege to speak on a veterans' affairs bill. I think I have spoken on most of them since I have been in this place because, as the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) has already said, veterans are very important people in our life. I think, when we talk about veterans' affairs, that we need to take an historical perspective on Australia's involvement in war.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a small nation and, even before it became a nation, its people were sending troops to war. From the Sudan through to Vietnam we have sent our troops to wars, mostly wars that were not our own. I would make an exception with that part of the Second World War when the Japanese came into the war and our country was definitely under threat.

So, for the most part, we have been generous in war. We have given our troops, our services, to other nations. Of course, in the beginning we were part of what was then known as the `mother country' and we are a part of the Commonwealth. I am sure all honourable members will, if they did not see it in person, certainly have seen replayed many times the then Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, saying that, as a consequence of Britain being at war, Australia was also at war.

In lots of cases we had no choice and we sent our personnel, mostly our men, to those wars. Ninety-four thousand men—mostly men—have died in those wars, starting with the Sudan, the Boxer rebellion and the Boer War. They were wars that are mostly forgotten now except for the two world wars, Korea and Vietnam. We have made an enormous sacrifice, one that is totally out of proportion to our population and to our strategic position in the world.

We also need to be aware of the profound effects that war has had, not only on those who took part in those encounters but on their families, and here I speak very much from personal experience. My father was in the navy practically all his working life so, as a child, I was used to his being away. Of course, during the war he was away virtually all the time so I never saw him very much then. I did not really get to know him until I was in my teens, and shortly after that he died. He died at the age of 58 from a heart disease but it was considered to have been due to war service. He was a TPI. So the toll on the families has been enormous and it is something we often forget.

There was a TV program recently about women in war and it showed families where the children were scared of their fathers. I have to say that I was one of those. I was to rejoice when my father came home and all I knew was that this man in a uniform came in and within five minutes had me in tears because he was trying to run the family as he thought it ought to be run. It was not his fault, it was not my mother's fault, it was the fault of the fact that he was at war. After the war he spent a considerable time in New Guinea and northern Australia on minesweepers, so once again he was absent. I think that profound effect on the families is something we ought to remember. For that reason the measures that we have brought in for veterans and for their families are very worthwhile, and an organisation like Legacy does a tremendous job in working with those people.

Several of the previous speakers have talked about the heroes of war, people from their own electorates. I made a speech in this place some time ago about two particular men I met last Anzac Day, Dr Jim Thorp and Mr John Robinson. They were both in their 90s and both had served in both world wars. Dr Thorp I alluded to in particular because unfortunately he died shortly after I met him on Anzac Day. He was 98 or 99 at that stage. He had gone to the First World War as a medical orderly. During the interim he trained as a doctor and he went back as a medical officer. Those people have made an enormous contribution and they are deserving of everything we can give them.

The member for Bass alluded to the kinds of things that Australia does for its veterans compared with other countries. I was very much aware as a child of men coming back from war and receiving an opportunity to study; their fees were paid if they wanted to undertake a course of study. They were given grants of land if they wanted to start a smallholding or a farm and also were given assistance with their house payments to buy a house. When my father died, my mother then took over the war service home loan, which was at a very low rate.

I think we have done and we continue to do a lot for our veterans, particularly in the area of health, and also in counselling. That is something that is fairly new. Unfortunately, there are still some people in the ADF who think that counselling is a bit wussy and something that only soft people need. The traumas of war, I think, are something we have overlooked for too long. In the First World War people were shot for deserting, for cowardice, and really they were suffering from what we now know as stress syndrome. Fortunately we have now recognised this with our Vietnam veterans, who had a doubly bad time because not only did they suffer from all those things that they saw and were engaged in but also they suffered to a great extent from rejection by a lot of people in their own community.

I have spoken of this before but I am very proud that there is a post-traumatic stress syndrome program at the St John of God Hospital in Richmond in my electorate which is going extremely well. Only last week it received an award from the Private Hospitals Association of New South Wales, and I will be writing to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) about that shortly. I hope he will write a letter congratulating the hospital on that success. I was fortunate to go and talk to some of the men who were engaged in its first program and they told me about some of the trauma they were going through in that program just recalling things that had happened to them and feeling as though they wanted to run away and get out of there. However, their comrades—they did not know each other before they went in but they were soon comrades because they had been in the same engagement—helped by saying, `No, hang in. It is going to be worthwhile.' Now I am getting feedback from those people saying what a benefit it was.

One particular case which I cannot resist mentioning, and I have sent a letter to the minister about this, was mentioned in a letter from one of the participants in that program who lives on the north coast of New South Wales. He wrote to the hospital and said that one of his fellow participants had come to see him recently for a cup of coffee. Not very sensational. But it was sensational because that man had driven from Sydney to the north coast and that is the first time he had been out on his own, virtually since he had left Vietnam, except to go to and from hospital. That was a big thing for him to get over that phobia, get in the car and drive and then sit down to talk with a mate. Those programs are definitely worthwhile and they are provided under our veterans' affairs programs.

I lived in the UK for some years from the early 1960s and it was not so long since the end of the war that people did not still talk about the situation. Their expression was, `All they gave us was a cardboard suit and our train fare home.' I think that is probably a rather extreme view of it. Of course, Britain was not in a position to be as generous as Australia was, because we had our own natural wealth on which to call; whereas Britain, of course, was devastated during the war, so her people did not do as well.

To come to the thrust of the bill, I need not go over it. It is a small bill, with three main issues. The one I want to talk about is the situation of women. Women played an extremely vital part in war. I am very conscious of this fact because I have in my electorate in the Blue Mountains a very strong ex-service women's group. The minister is to meet them fairly soon and he will have a long schedule there. These women are very active: they keep together and support each other. They come to me when one of their members is having trouble getting into hospital for an operation or is having any problem at all, and I am very glad to help them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That instant access doesn't happen with health, does it!
—They certainly do have instant access to me, as do all my constituents.
—I'm talking about the hospital.

—The state, of course, is a bit of a problem there—particularly in New South Wales. But women did play a very vital part in war and they will continue to do so. I have mixed feelings about this particular issue. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has taken us to task for doing exactly what the opposition had promised to do before the election.
—We told them. You told them the opposite. Don't try and get out of it.
—The opposition was going to bring in this measure over a period of 10 years. We are bringing it in over 20 years.
—And that makes a difference?
—It certainly does make a difference.
—Why don't you tell them that.

—The government is easing it in over 20 years. Like all the other social security measures, it is being applied to veterans. As my colleague the honourable member for Bass has said, this will affect very few women who have served in past wars, because most of them are over that age now.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that the age equalisation issue has been a vexed one and, as a matter of principle, as women strive for equality, this is one of the measures that we need to take. Of course, we have to acknowledge that it is going to affect some women, particularly older women and, in the case of the social security pension, the women who are now in their late 50s. For that reason, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) has set up a working group, which I coordinate, to look at ways of implementing this measure—which comes in next July—in order to minimise its effect on such women.

One of those particular women is in my electorate. She is now 58. She is a very modern woman who believes in equality. She is still working. She was a person who suffered from what we would call the old regimes. She was in the Commonwealth Public Service and, at that time, women had to leave the Service when they got married. We all agree that that was a pretty antiquated law, and it does not apply now.

Nevertheless, women who were caught up in that system are now reaching retirement age and they wish to have their pension at the time that they expected they would. After this particular woman got married, she had children and then went back into the work force. Now she is being squeezed out of her job at the age of 58, because her employer thinks it is time she moved over for someone younger. While supporting the legislation which this government has put through, and which was supported by the opposition, and also supporting its reflection in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), as a woman, I acknowledge that it is a difficult issue and one that we have to handle very carefully. For that reason, I am glad that it is not going to have too much of an effect on the women veterans.

However, we are looking in a caring way at the issue for women in civilian life. We are working to minimise the effect on the most affected group of women. The women who will have to work until they are 65 know that. They are in their 40s now. They are mostly women who are in the work force. Many of them have superannuation, so the effect on them will not be so profound. I sincerely hope that women who are now in their 40s and who have to wait until they are 60 will not have to go to war and will not have to apply for a veterans pension—simply because I hope this country never has to enter those sorts of engagements again.

This veterans bill reflects issues in the social security legislation. The bill that was debated earlier was to bring in more measures to help veterans. Like my colleague the honourable member for Bass, I commend the current minister and his predecessor. They have done a fantastic job. Next year will be the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II. Veterans will be very visible. I think most members will also be very visible and will be out there supporting the veterans who play such an important role in our community. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank those who have contributed to the debate, and in particular you, Mr Deputy Speaker, who had a second bite of the cherry this morning. I especially thank our two female colleagues—if we can call them that—
—What do you mean, `call'?

—You are colleagues. I especially thank them in the sense that they have given a different perspective to the debate, particularly the honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) who talked about her experiences as a young girl when her father returned from war. She mentioned the Australia Remembers program. I am not going to say much about that because if I did I would go on all day and my colleague in the chair would not be happy. However, I want to say that we will not forget the women who stayed at home. We will not forget the people who worked in the factories and on the farms while the present veterans were overseas. They will all be part of the Australia Remembers program.

PARA.TAB: The opposition spokesman, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), mentioned that he will take particular delight in talking to the female veterans who are going to be affected by this legislation. I interjected and asked, `Where are you going to meet them—in a phone box?' My point was that in effect there are only a very small number of them.

I will put this on the record. The female veterans who are likely to claim service pensions will mainly come from two conflicts. The first one was Korea and Malaya. The Australian involvement in Korea and Malaya finished in 1963. A female veteran would have had to be at least 23 before being sent to the operational area, but it could be expected that she would be older. At the minimum possible age, those women would be 55 years old in 1995. Recent grants of service pension to female veterans are as follows: 1991, four; 1992, two; 1993, two; 1994, one. None of these was born any later than 6 January 1937. That is, the youngest is already 57 years of age. Any further grants are not expected to be affected by the age equalisation provisions.

The other place of conflict was Vietnam. Records of participants in that conflict have been examined very closely. The number of female veterans with qualifying service from that conflict totals only 52. Of those, 19 are either pensioners already or have passed away. One lives in New Zealand and could apply for service pension only if she returns to live in Australia. Of the remaining 32 who would be affected by the age equalisation provisions, if they wish to claim a service pension at the minimum age, the number affected and the ages they would need to attain are as follows: three at 55; six at 55.5; three at 56; nine at 56.5; eight at 57; one at 57.5; and two at 58.

The point I am trying to make here—and I will not comment on all the extraneous things that the opposition spokesman talked about—is that there are not a lot of people who are going to be affected in the veterans' affairs portfolio. At the end of the day, I feel quite comfortable with the provision and I do not think, as I say, that there will be too many people who will be too worried about it. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation announced.
Motion (by Mr Sciacca)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Consideration resumed from 19 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 will amend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SI(S) Act) and the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993. Those acts formed the centrepiece of a package of superannuation legislation which received royal assent on 30 November 1993 and which gave effect to the new prudential arrangements for superannuation that the Treasurer announced on 21 October 1992.

PARA.TAB: This bill makes a number of amendments, many of a technical nature, to the abovementioned acts aimed at further enhancing and refining the operation of those acts. I turn to the main provisions outlined in these amendments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Allowing certain non-bank financial institutions to offer `approved guarantees'

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow certain non-bank financial institutions to offer guarantees required under the SI(S) Act.

Currently, only approved banks and the Commonwealth, states or territories can offer the guarantees required under the SI(S) Act. Building societies, credit unions and similar organisations which are subject to supervision under the various state financial institutions codes are considered to be institutions which should also be able to offer the guarantees required under the SI(S) Act and this bill amends the SI(S) Act accordingly.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Allowing `in-house' investments in certain non-bank financial institutions

PARA.TAB: An `in-house asset' is essentially a loan to, or investment in, a standard employer sponsor of the fund—or an associate of such an employer sponsor—and the SI(S) Act places restrictions, for prudential reasons, on the level of such investments.

The bill amends the SI(S) Act to treat deposits in certain non-bank financial institutions—which are subject to prudential supervision—in the same manner as deposits in an approved bank with regard to determining if they are `in-house assets'.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Applications for the issue of a superannuation interest and application to become a standard employer-sponsor

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that the trustee cannot accept a person as a member of a public offer entity unless that person has applied in the appropriate manner and has received relevant information—determined by the Commissioner—regarding the entity before doing so.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Acquisition of certain assets from members of regulated superannuation funds

PARA.TAB: The SI(S) Act imposes a general prohibition on the acquisition of assets from members, subject to a limited exception in relation to funds with less than five members—excluded superannuation funds—provided the asset acquired is business real property. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that an excluded superannuation fund can only acquire business real property from a member—or relative of a member—if the property is business real property in the member's—or relative's—principal business.

This ensures that the right balance is struck between allowing the acquisition of business real property from members of excluded funds and recognising the dangers—from a prudential, retirement incomes and taxation revenue perspective—in such an approach.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Public offer superannuation funds and equal representation

PARA.TAB: The SI(S) Act currently requires a standard employer sponsored fund which is a public offer fund to have an independent trustee. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow such funds the option of either having an independent trustee or having equal numbers of employer and member representatives involved in the trusteeship of the fund. This provides funds with greater flexibility in organising their trusteeship while at the same time ensuring that members are protected—in the first instance by having a trustee who is independent and in the second by having direct involvement in the fund via equal representation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Existing trustee may give notice of retirement

PARA.TAB: A fundamental principle of the SI(S) Act is that superannuation entities should be in the control of a single party—the trustees—who take full responsibility for the fund. However, the Corporations Law currently requires that superannuation entities which are public offer entities have dual responsible parties—the trustee and the management company. The SI(S) Act enables these public offer entities to change to have a single party in control of the fund. In many cases this will involve the trustee retiring and the management company taking over the role of trustee.

The effective and smooth operation of this changeover may be hampered if the existing trustee is required to hold a meeting of beneficiaries before retiring—as the governing rules of some superannuation entities may require. To overcome this problem, and therefore to ensure a smooth changeover, the bill amends the SI(S) Act to provide that such a requirement in the governing rules of a fund has no effect.

The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow the minister to approve disclosure of protected information—if it is in the public interest to do so—to the public at large, rather than just to particular members of the public. At the same time the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that appropriate protection is provided to an individual by only allowing disclosure of information that relates to the private affairs of an individual where such disclosure would not be unreasonable in the circumstances.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Allowing the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to provide protected information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow officers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, ISC, to provide protected information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. Protected information is information relating to the affairs of a fund which the ISC has obtained in the course of carrying out its supervisory duties.

While the ISC is allowed to provide such information to bodies such as the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Taxation Office there is no allowance to provide such information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. The Superannuation Complaints Tribunal commenced operation on 1 July 1994 and provides a quick and fair mechanism, which previously did not exist, for dealing with member complaints regarding superannuation. The restriction on the provision of protected information, where that information is directly relevant to a particular complaint, is hampering the effective operation of the complaints tribunal. The amendment allows the ISC to provide such relevant information to the complaints tribunal.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Approved purposes of, and payments to beneficiaries in, an approved deposit fund

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure consistency between related provisions in the act which deal with the purposes for which an approved deposit fund may be maintained and payments to beneficiaries. This clarifies the existing obligations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Disqualified persons not to be custodians

PARA.TAB: The SI(S) Act currently restricts disqualified persons from being trustees or investment managers of superannuation entities. There is however no similar requirement on custodians. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to address this problem and ensure that custodians are subject to similar `eligibility' requirements to those applying to trustees and investment managers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Removal of trustees of public offer entities

PARA.TAB: The bill inserts a new requirement into the SI(S) Act to prevent another party from trying to exert undue influence on a trustee by threatening to remove the trustee unless the trustee complies with that party's requests. The amendment ensures that no other party would have the power to exercise such influence by ensuring that, unless the regulations provide otherwise, no person, other than the Commissioner, can remove a trustee of a public offer entity.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Allowing exempt public sector superannuation schemes to become subject to the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, termed the SRC Act, to allow exempt public sector superannuation schemes to become subject to the act. Currently only regulated superannuation funds, and approved deposit funds, are subject to the SRC Act and thus only members of those funds can make use of the superannuation complaints tribunal.

Many public sector superannuation schemes will not be regulated funds. Instead they will be exempt public sector superannuation schemes and members of such schemes will not therefore be able to use the complaints tribunal.

In some cases this is acceptable as there are other appropriate complaints mechanisms available for members of such schemes. However some schemes believe their members should have and need access to the complaints tribunal. The amendment enables such schemes to become subject to the SRC Act and so have such access to the tribunal.
More detailed information on the amendments made by this bill and an explanation of those amendments is contained in the explanatory memorandum.
The amendments made by this bill have no revenue implications.
I commend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of this debate I want to open by referring to procedures which have been adopted at the same time as, but not in any way related to, the establishment of this committee. Whereas before the opposition was able to consider a minister's remarks adequately because we had prior notification, the second reading speech having been given at the time the legislation was introduced, we are now in no position to do that and that is an impediment on debate in this place.

PARA.TAB: A consequence in the context of this legislation is that I am, with my prepared remarks, now going to repeat a great deal of what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) has just had to say, which I would not have had to do under the former arrangements. I think that tends to waste people's time. Not knowing what the parliamentary secretary was going to say in his second reading speech, I naturally set out to put my comments in the context of the legislation. Had the parliamentary secretary not done as he did, it would not have been a matter of great concern.

On those two grounds I must say I regret the abandonment of the old procedure because the opposition is not in a position to respond to the second reading speech. Remember that ministers, or parliamentary secretaries, as the case may be, always have the resources of government to help them get their words together and to get their thoughts in some sort of logical sequence, and that is not available to the opposition, in this case the coalition. I think it does have the effect of stifling debate as well as causing me, on this occasion anyway, to indulge in some tedious repetition which probably will be in breach of standing orders, Mr Deputy Speaker.

This bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, was introduced into the House on 19 September after passing through the Senate on 30 August. It sets out to amend the Superannuation Industry Supervision Act 1993, known as the SI(S) Act, and the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, or the SRC Act.

The SI(S) Act effectively began operating on 1 July of this year. The principal act provides the legislative framework for the prudent management of certain superannuation funds, particularly the security of members' moneys, and for certain minimum standards. The principal act has already been amended once this year by the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994.

Amendments to the SI(S) Act and to the SRC Act currently before us are aimed at enhancing the operations of those acts. The coalition does not oppose this bill because the amendments represent primarily housekeeping measures. As the parliamentary secretary has already pointed out, there is no financial impact arising from these measures.

The amendment bill before us is largely the result of the willingness of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the ISC, to listen to the concerns and recommendations of the superannuation industry. The performance of the ISC can be largely measured by the degree to which the industry can work with it. Also, according to Senator Watson, who is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, the ISC has developed a good working relationship with the select committee and with his office. The ISC should be commended on its performance to date and I sincerely hope that other agencies, such as the Australian Taxation Office, can take its example and be less confrontational.

One matter that relates to the operation of the ISC and the need for amendment bills is that under part 29 of the SI(S) Act the ISC has the power to modify provisions of the act, either temporarily or permanently. Modifications of a permanent nature are of concern. They effectively have the potential to change the intention of the act. Of course, modification orders are gazetted, but they are not subject to the scrutiny that amendment bills or regulations would receive in the normal course of events. Parliament, by allowing modifications, is delegating its legislative role to a government agency in circumstances where there is no form of legislated requirement for review. To the best of my knowledge, to date the ISC has used its power to modify the SI(S) Act in a responsible manner, so I am anticipating a concern.

I believe this is an issue to which members of the House should give consideration. Should we be prepared to delegate our legislative role in this way or should we take a more active position in protecting the legislative workings of the parliament? That is the question I want honourable members to consider.

It would be preferable for permanent modifications to the SI(S) Act to be achieved by legislative change, with the ISC modifications being used only as a temporary measure. A majority of the amendments made by this bill affect the SI(S) Act. The bill, as it was originally introduced into the Senate, has already been amended. Many of the amendments are of a minor and technical nature. Where I mention in the course of my remarks the relevant division of the bill, it should be assumed that I am referring to those divisions in part 2 that are amendments to the SI(S) Act, unless I indicate otherwise.

Division 3 allows certain non-bank financial institutions to offer what are known as approved guarantees. This measure relates to the standard of investments. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow certain non-bank financial institutions to offer guarantees required under the SI(S) Act. Currently, only approved banks, and the Commonwealth, states or territories, can offer guarantees required under the SI(S) Act.

The bill also amends the SI(S) Act to enable building societies, credit unions and similar organisations, which are subject to supervision under the various state financial institutions codes, to also be able to offer such guarantees. As well, division 3 allows `in-house' investments in certain non-bank financial institutions.

An `in-house asset' is essentially a loan to, or an investment in, a standard employer sponsor of the fund, or an associate of such an employer sponsor, and the SI(S) Act places restrictions, for prudential reasons, on the level of such investments.

The bill amends the SI(S) Act to treat deposits in certain non-bank financial institutions, which are subject to prudential supervision, in the same manner as deposits in an approved bank, with the objective of determining whether they are in-house assets. The effect of this amendment is significant, as the SI(S) Act restricts the in-house assets of regulated superannuation funds to 10 per cent of the total assets in most cases. What it does is rope in the non-bank institutions, such as building societies and the like.

Division 7 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that a trustee cannot accept a person as a member of a public offer entity, unless that person has applied in the appropriate manner and has received relevant information, of a calibre determined by the commissioner, about the entity beforehand.

Division 11 amends section 66 of the SI(S) Act. The SI(S) Act imposes a general prohibition on the acquisition of assets from members, subject to a limited exception for funds with less than five members, known as excluded superannuation funds, provided the asset acquired is business real property.

The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that an excluded superannuation fund can only acquire business real property from a member, or relative of a member, if the property is business real property in the member's or relative's principal business.

The SI(S) Act currently requires a standard employer sponsored fund, which is a public offer fund, to have an independent trustee. Division 12 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow such funds the option of either having an independent trustee, or having equal numbers of employer and member representatives, involved in the trusteeship of the fund. This provides funds with greater flexibility in organising their trusteeship, while at the same time ensuring that members are protected in the first instance by having a trustee who is independent, and, in the second, by having direct involvement in the fund via equal representation.

Employee representatives need not necessarily be members of the superannuation fund. They are usually representatives nominated by the members of a fund, a trade union or other organisation representing the interests of those members. There is much merit in having employee trustees. Even where the option of an independent trustee is taken up, it would be useful if funds were required to have at least one representative from the fund membership who is, in the vernacular, from the shop floor.

Such a fund member representative would benefit the prudential protection of the fund and reassure workers that the fund is sound. It is a matter I believe the ISC should give serious consideration to. It is also a matter that Senator Watson has been pursuing for some time with no response from the government so far. Overall, this amendment to sections 91 to 93 of the SI(S) Act will undoubtedly provide funds with much greater flexibility in organising their trusteeship. It will also ensure that members are protected by having a trustee who is independent and by having direct involvement in the fund by means of equal representation.

Division 13 allows for existing trustees to give a notice of retirement without a need to call a meeting of beneficiaries. A fundamental principle of the SI(S) Act is that superannuation entities should be in control of a single party—the trustees who take full responsibility for the fund. However, corporations law currently requires that superannuation entities which are public offer entities have dually responsible parties comprising the trustees and the management company. The SI(S) Act enables these public offer entities to change to a single party in control of the fund. In many cases this will involve the trustee retiring and the management company taking over the role of trustee.

The effective and smooth operation of this changeover may be hampered if the existing trustee is required to hold a meeting of beneficiaries before retiring, as the governing rules of some superannuation entities may in fact require. To overcome that problem and therefore to ensure a smoother changeover, the bill amends the SI(S) Act to provide that such a requirement in the governing rules of the fund will have no effect. This is a commonsense measure. It will eliminate the unnecessary expense to superannuation funds where an existing trustee retires as a result of provisions in the SI(S) Act.

Division 14 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow the minister to approve disclosure of otherwise protected information, if it is in the public interest to do so, to the public at large rather than to particular members of the public. How the public interest is defined is always interesting. I have no doubt it will be the same in this case. Naturally enough, the public interest as perceived by the minister could be very different from that of an impartial observer. Where such disclosure does occur, I hope it is only undertaken on the advice of the ISC. It is essential that political chicanery not be correlated with the public interest. At the same time, the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that appropriate protection is provided to an individual by only allowing disclosure of information that relates to the private affairs of an individual where such disclosure would not be unreasonable in the circumstances.

The ISC is currently able to disclose information to the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Securities Commission. These amendments will allow the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to receive information obtained by the ISC. The effective operation of the tribunal which also commenced on 1 July 1994 can only be improved by these amendments.

Keeping in mind the Privacy Act and the need to ensure individual privacy, where the ISC does hand information over to the tribunal this should only occur where the person concerned has given the ISC written authorisation. The disclosure of information to the tribunal should only be done where authority to do so has been given because it protects the privacy of the person concerned and it protects the ISC against any possible future dispute as to whether it was reasonable to disclose the information.

Division 15 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure consistency between related provisions in the act which deal with the purposes for which an approved deposit fund may be maintained, and payments to beneficiaries also. This clarifies the existing obligation. The SI(S) Act currently restricts disqualified persons from being trustees or investment managers of superannuation entities. There is, however, no similar requirement on custodians. Division 17 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to address this problem and ensure that custodians are subject to similar eligibility requirements to those applying to trustees and to investment managers. Naturally, custodians play an important role in safeguarding the assets of their clients in their contractual relationships with a trustee or an investment manager. It is more important that these sorts of prudential controls extend to custodians.

Division 18 deals with the removal of trustees of public offer entities in section 60A. The bill inserts a new requirement into this SI(S) Act to prevent another party from trying to exert undue influence on a trustee by threatening to remove the trustee unless the trustee complies with that party's requests. This should serve to reinforce the perceived and intended real independence of trustees by requiring that the government rules of public offer funds allow a trustee to be removed only by the commissioner, unless the removal is of a kind to be specified in later regulations.

Division 18A requires the trustees of an exempt public sector superannuation scheme that is subject to the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act to set up arrangements for dealing with inquiries or complaints. Clauses 50 to 52 enable regulations to be made bringing currently exempt public sector superannuation schemes within the operation of the S(RC) Act. This also is a welcome measure. It will increase the accessibility of the tribunal by public sector fund members and ensure that those funds that elect to become subject to the SI(S) Act have an internal resolution mechanism.

This latest amendment rectifies an earlier problem. Previously, if a fund did not have an internal resolution mechanism a member could not go to the tribunal. Clauses 50 to 52 allow state and territory governments to legislate to subject their public superannuation schemes to the operations of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. Ultimately, the decision to do so rests with the states, although to date I believe only Victoria and New South Wales have opted to stay out.

Mr Deputy Speaker, superannuation policy under Labor has been a litany of wasted opportunities. The very rapidity of legislative changes to superannuation policy has created uncertainty where stability should exist. Superannuation is not as widely accepted as it should be as the preferred vehicle for retirement saving. Management fees, taxes levied on moneys going into and out of funds, the legislative uncertainty and the lack of choice of superannuation schemes have led to many people challenging the worth of superannuation as it is now constituted.

The superannuation guarantee charge, the SGC, continues to be a major concern for employers. Imposing the costs of the SGC predominantly on employers is an impost that cannot be afforded. For every employer, the SGC is another hefty payroll tax that discourages investment in Australia and impacts negatively on possible future job creation. If the SGC exists to fund the retirement of an employer's employees, why should the employer foot the retirement bill? It is a social matter. Employees should also bear responsibility for their own superannuation contributions. Only by contributing towards the cost of their own retirement will employees realise the cost involved and gain an appreciation of the ownership of their future retirement income. Of course, there is the additional impost of complying with the SGC. This is just another cost that is added to the already long list of costs incurred over and above the total wages bill. Superannuation provides one method by which Australians can maximise our national savings.

The government is in total disarray when it comes to a savings policy. The FitzGerald report on national savings advocated several necessary changes to government policy on superannuation that would assist in increasing the rate of savings. FitzGerald recommended, amongst other things, superannuation savings accounts and increased competition between the current players and, of course, future players.

At the last election, the coalition advocated the establishment of retirement savings accounts. These accounts would have enjoyed the same superannuation tax concessions that we were advocating for superannuation policies. Our objective in advocating retirement savings accounts was twofold: to expand the range of choice available to individuals and to allow banks and other financial institutions to compete with superannuation funds in the provision of superannuation schemes. These savings accounts would also have been available to low income and seasonal workers, thereby maintaining the tax office as the collector of government revenue, not as the manager of superannuation accounts.

Greater competition in the provision of superannuation is anathema to Labor and the reasons are crystal clear: Labor is looking after its mates. Rather than introducing greater competition to the provision of superannuation, the government has closed the door on greater competition in order to protect existing super funds and, particularly, the role of the ACTU in occupational superannuation. The ACTU has been a constant opponent of greater competition and seems, once again, to have exercised its veto. To date, the ACTU has won all the battles, leaving the community as the loser.

To the ACTU and this government, it seems superannuation has little to do with retirement income policy, and more to do with industrial relations and taxation. The drive for award based superannuation has taken little, if any, account of productivity. It takes no account of a firm's capacity to pay, and it denies individuals the right to best decide where their superannuation contributions should go. Nearly all award based superannuation contributions are paid into union dominated superannuation funds. The award based superannuation system is made worse because of the number of awards that cover many occupational groupings. These numerous superannuation schemes all have different conditions and obligations which must be met by employers. This makes the cost of complying with the superannuation guarantee all that much higher.

Prior to Labor coming to power in March 1983, there were no taxes on contributions and fund earnings, and tax was only payable on five per cent of an individual's lump sum entitlement at the individual's marginal rate. There are now six taxes on superannuation that tax employer contributions, super fund investment income, the lump sums of those individuals under 55 years, ad infinitum. Superannuation has become Labor's milch cow. Labor's approach is simple: if it moves, tax it.

This approach to retirement incomes has discouraged and confused many people about the benefits of superannuation. For individuals to fully fund their retirement, they need more than just the superannuation guarantee. They also need the desire to make their own contributions. By discouraging individual superannuation contributions, the government is actively discouraging the community from saving for retirement. In the Financial Review of 17 August this year, Barrie Dunstan wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Governments, as well as consumers, may need educating, considering that research group Mintel has found that, relative to many European countries, the level of targeted retirement income here is low. Taking the Australian level of retirement income from government pensions and privately financed savings as the base of 100, Mintel's figures put the relative welfare index of Italy at 196, Spain at 186, Sweden at 162 and Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg at 147.

It is obvious that the governments of those countries are encouraging a much higher rate of retirement income for their citizens. Of course, this will also have the potential of translating into higher rates of national savings.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will announce a revised superannuation policy, in the lead-up to the next election, that will try to come to grips with many of these issues. It will not necessarily mirror that of the 1993 election, but it will be committed to increasing the flexibility of the superannuation system and reducing the compliance costs of businesses. As I stated earlier, the coalition does not oppose this bill as it is largely a housekeeping measure that, we have been pleased to note, was drafted in consultation with industry groups.
Debate (on motion by Mr Robert Brown) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 9 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) To what extent are ABC TV programs captioned for the hearing impaired.
(2) Will the ABC TV news at 7 p.m. be captioned; if so, when.
(3) What budgetary provision has been made for captioning in 1994-95 and ensuing years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Supertext subtitles have been available on selected ABC programs and some purchased BBC programs since 1983. In total, the ABC now broadcasts on average 20 hours of subtitled programs per week.

In order to provide a balance of subtitled programs, during any given week, the ABC aims to provide at least two hours of young people's programs, one arts program, one documentary, one drama, the Wednesday special, one religious program and a movie. Australian material is a priority.
ABC TV's Late Edition News introduced supertext subtitles on 27 August 1990.

(2) The ABC and the Australian Caption Centre have and will continue to investigate cost effective options for the supertext subtitling of this service. However, as the ABC produces seven separate state based 7 p.m. news broadcasts each day, the logistics and costs are significant
(3) The Department of Human Services and Health has advised that Budget funding provided to the Australian Caption Centre (ACC) in 1994-95 on a recurrent basis will be as follows:
ABC Late News Sub-titling—$116,768
Video Captioning Project—$114,198
This level of funding provided to the ACC under the Disability Services Program is on-going and indexed for inflation.
The ABC will maintain the level of funding provided to the Australian Caption Centre for 1994-95 at $500,000.
Both the ABC and the Australian Caption Centre are continuing to examine technological and other methods which may lead to increased output of subtitled product.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 27 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will reduced funding of CSIRO between 1994 and 1997 affect the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre; if so, how.
(2) Will adequate funds be provided between 1994 and 1997 to enable the Centre to continue its work.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In 1993-4, CSIRO provided funding of $326,000 to the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre's core budget and intends to maintain this level of funding throughout the triennium from 1994-5 to 1996-7.

(2) The majority of funds for the Centre come from non-Commonwealth Government sources.
